reviewText:
Games for Windows Live has been removed!

DiRT Free* (get it?) is a rally sports game.
FREE DLCs, No region-lock anymore, Steam achivements, Trading Cards and a full controller support. What else could you want ? A decent Rally championship! That's what!

DiRT series is my favourate rally sports series. It's also my most dissapointing racing game series ever. Why ? I'll tell you why!
DiRT games have great physics, great handling, great music and great graphics. Everything sounds perfect, doesn't it ? But it just sounds like that.

DiRT2 has muddy forest tracks. No snow tracks.
DiRT3 has snow and desert tracks. No jungle / forest tracks. This right here is pretty R-Tarded.
DiRT is supposed to be a successor to the good 'ol Colin McRae series. We all loved McRae games for the Rally Championships. Realistic tracks with decent length. Lots of tracks in one country and lots of countries in a tournament/championship. Point and time system was well in place. - This is all gone in the DiRT series.

In WRC4 or in old Colin McRae games you could drive through 6 tracks in Finland. Rank 1st, 3rd, 3rd, 2nd, 1st, 1st and come out 1st overall in Finland. Then proceed to Greek finish 2nd overall in greek move to UK. Finish 4th overall in UK and then judging by that you finish 2nd in the Championship (only there's like 8 countries not just 3).
Yeah, this is not happening in DiRT3 so let's take the look at the biggest flaws of DiRT3:

- Tracks are only 1-3 minutes long (under 3-5 minutes is unacceptable!)
- No decent championship mode (you can only do like 2-3 tracks in a row. WOW! Not even a full country tournament. Let alone speak of a decent championship with multiple countries in it)
- All countries and terrains are not there (no desert tracks for an example)

But DiRT3 has huge pros tho:

+ The best physics you can find in a rally game
+ Best handling in a rally game
+ Well detailed tracks and good graphics
+ Good music

DiRT4 needs to copy tournaments/championships from WRC4 while keeping the handling and physics of DiRT3 and we would have the perfect rally game!
It would be the best rally game to date!

Conclusion: Altho the tracks are short and there's no real championships in this game...It's still the best on the market. Yes, WRC4 has the perfect tracks and a good championship mode but the way cars handle...and the physics...they're pathetic, really.
Get DiRT3 if you want to rally...Or any of the older Colin McRae games if you can bare the dated graphics and maybe the lack of a good controller support.

*The complete edition is a free upgrade to the previous DiRT3 version owners.

reviewText:
I have played nearly all Codemasters' rally games, from the iconic Collin McRae Rally 2.0 to the game we have up now, DiRT3. Collin McRae Rally 0.4 was until now the best of them all, leaving a high level to beat and defeating its trone despite being a 10 year old game. No wonder at Codies they have the formula for the perfect Rally game and they have showed it off throughout the decade, and now DiRT3 is the peak of the saga.

Despite changing the name from Collin McRae Rally to DiRT (after the Scottish Rallying legend death, RIP), the essence keeps the same. It is a casual Rally game with a stunning variety of cars ranging from competitors on the WRC to classic icons like the Renault Alpine, the Peugeot 405 Pikes Peak, the Audi Quattro, etc. The amount of tracks and routes is astonishing, quite well thought and designed to make each stage on a rally be different as it was on the CMR games.

DiRT3 though includes even more game modes and a partnership with Ken Block. That could only have an awesome effect on the game, and indeed it did. There's a huge extension on the Xgames field featuring Rallycross events and buggies among others. So as to the Ken Block thing, there's the famous Gymkhana translated into a game mode in which you  hoon round an area full of obstacles. Plus, of course, his breathtaking Ford Fiesta is included and ridiculously well made. There's also a Gymkhana competition game mode in which you have to work out drifting tricks to earn points to beat other rivals, which adds more excitement to the matter. Ken Block's WRC car is also included in the game, and some cars include a custom Ken Block inspired livery. All this new stuff doesn't leave the initial rally concept apart.

Now that it is fully Steamworks, at Codemasters have made the best of the opportunity to patch certain bugs mostly regarding to shadows and general performance. Another good point from this is the online matchmaking. Although it has few bugs (online is never perfect on any game), matchmaking is quick but sometimes it kicks players itself. Joyride is particularly fun, and it is always challenging to challenge other users on a rally.

Graphically, it's pretty nice. Light effects are everywhere and make the landscape realistic and beautiful. Textures are detailed and fit quite well with a tough-worked modelling of the landscape and track. Cars in that field are well made, some better than others but generally right. In a rally game the dust coming out of the wheels on sand must be dense and accurate, and it actually is in this game. As a tradition in Codemasters, the game is well built and rarely has FPS drops.

Handling is amazingly well made. You can feel the difference between surfaces and every car is completely different from each other. Rallies are then tricky and great fun, top notch work from Codemasters there.
If you have never played any racing game on manual gearbox before then this is the time to start off. You'll have to rev up the engine in the shorter gears to make a proper drift and oh, with automatic shifting you cannot.

AI as in all other Codemasters games is superb. Although you'll only face it directly in Rallycross and most Xgames trials, AI won't be dumb and will even make mistakes, resulting in amazing crashes which you have to avoid. More excitement to races.

The best way to play it is with a Xbox 360 controller. It is the best option for its triggers and full compatibility. Remember that this game used to work on Games For Windows Live, Microsoft brand as Xbox is so...

Codemasters have gone in the right direction when making a honourable successor of the iconic Colin McRae saga. 100% worth all the money.

10/10

I had played a little bit of DiRT 3 in its GFWL incarnation, but I can't say it really grabbed me. Then the Complete Edition came around and I figured I may as well at least give it another shot, and I'm glad I did. I still have the same problems I did with it then, but I think I've found myself enjoying it regardless.

First of all, I suppose some historical context is in order. If you're not aware, the original DiRT is revered by rally fans for its realistic portrayal of the sport, closer to the simulation end of the racing scale than arcade. In DiRT 2 some concessions were made in order to make the game more accessible to a wider audience, but by and large it was still a rally game through and through. DiRT 3 adds yet more accessibility to the formula, though still manages to provide a high skill ceiling for the old fans. DiRT Showdown, which came after this, diluted the rally roots of the game practically out of existence, to the point that it turned off fans of the older style of game that was increasingly disappearing. Then comes DiRT Rally which is now in Early Access and promises a return to the true DiRT formula, focusing solely on rally driving and cutting back on accessibility features like the rewind mechanic.

Now that we've covered some of the history, why does it matter? Well, when it comes to racing games, I tend to prefer games on the arcade end of the spectrum. Games like Mario Kart, where you hold on the gas the whole time, building up the longest drifts you can, are my bag, so to speak. Sometimes I go out of my comfort zone and find games I really enjoy, like Driver San Francisco, but generally the closer to simulation a racing game gets, the less I like it. Nothing necessarily wrong with them; I just don't like playing them. So why would I ever try DiRT 3? Even though it's the most accessible of the real" DiRT games

reviewText:
9/10 for me, however, there are some drawbacks.

What I really liked:
- beautiful graphics and diverse enviroments. This game came out 4 years ago, yet it's still mindblowing. You can drive in four continents, in cities, on the savanna, among pine trees and nice lakes. In one word, I enjoyed all the maps and places.
- great sound effects and musics.
- on casual, it is a piece of a cake, while on advanced, it is like a simulator. I played on advanced and from the driver's view, and it imitated real driving experience more than well.
- imaginative interface. High five to the guys who designed it.
- cars from all types and ages. Everybody can find his/her own favorite.
- random (I assume) events occur during the races. Rarely, but cars drift out, pile up, etc.


Things I didn't like. (hated sometimes):
- the game gets repetitive. Don't know if it is like that in real rally, but the tracks are mirrored. Not once, not twice, but many times. Oh man, it's a new season, another chance to prove yourself - says my mechanic. Then it turns out the race is the same, but this time it is backwards. I was extremely bored after the 3rd season.
- the game cheats. The f***ing bots on advanced go like a madman, regardless of the conditions and the laws of physics. Let me give you an example: I went let's say 3:02 on advanced (hard) and achieved 6th place out of 8. Then I switched to casual (easy) and did it in 2:55 and was first, AND the bot with 3:02 was 2nd. Basically, the game creates their lap times after you did yours, the only difference is, that on advanced it lets you win a very few times, while on casual the time you went could mean you a podium. This is not how selecting difficulty should work.

The game has lots of opportunities and challenges, so the hardcore drivers can satisfy themselves.

reviewText:
First, let me say DiRT 3 is a masterpiece on its own. The community asked for more Rally races as opposed to RallyCross and other game modes? Great. Code Masters not only emphasize rally racing in the campaign, but also add in a bunch more new game modes (such as gymkana) without managing to take the focus away from rally racing. The game looks beautiful despite running on Code Master's proprietary engine known for using little system resources. The gameplay itself is fast and fun, and provides many different assists for racers of all skills to race like Colin McRae.

However, there was outcry as the original version used GFWL, an annoying DRM I didn't really mind but everyone else did. So, Code Masters being the amazing devs they are, decided to remove it. Not only this, but the new version includes all of the DLC, which alone probably equals the cost of the complete edition. And the best part? The update is completely free for existing DiRT owners. Code Masters: Doin things right.

EDIT: I want to address something I haven't seen in too many reviews. I dunno how active the community is but there are a bevy of multiplayer modes, of which many if not all are available for split screen coop. A rarity in today's gaming world.

reviewText:
Dirt 3 - Complete Edition is the no-GFWL version of Dirt 3.
In other words, you can play this game without caring about windows live software and all DLCs are included for free.
To put it down perfectly;
Dirt 3 - Complete Edition is the remake any game with bad DRM needs in order to have its digital content expanded with the 100% fully free material that should had already been there at release.

In other words, as a release product, for me personally, it's the ultimate example for no-DLC ruled full edition game productions.

Everyone who already owns a copy of Dirt 3 gets to have a copy Dirt 3 - Complete Edition for free. Steam version gets automatically added on library while owners from hard copies get to have a free digital copy of Dirt 3 - Complete Edition by registering their old product SN.


IF YOU DON'T OWN A COPY OF THE OLD DIRT 3:
Dirt 3 - Complete Edition is the worthy ancestor of Dirt 2. It's an awesome rally game. There are obvious improvements on graphics and physics as well as on some game play options like game modes. You get to see a wide variety of cars and an equally nice set of tracks to run on. There's also those tracks where you can do your tricks and drifts and donuts. There's less advertising of Ken Block (who I personally think is good for doing tricks and drifts but is very bad at rallying) and there's a very nice set of OST music tracks to enjoy. One major thing I miss from Dirt2 was the Malaysia set of tracks. They were PERFECT for me. Instead you get to run on some nice Kenya and Finland tracks but you will never get the jungly feeling Malaysia had. I spent on teh old Dirt 3 more than 60 hours and enjoyed it a LOT. It was an nice game but never had the chance to buy the DCLs. Now with the Dirt 3 - Complete Edition it was all posible so I decided to run and beat everything for once more. It was awesome.
Conpared to the old version, this one is even better and oh hell yes its worth buying!

Comparing to the Dirt 3.

PROS:
✔ Dirt 3 - Complete Edition works without Games For Windows Live. Need to say more? You don't get to bash your head solving issues about disconnection problems and account syncing crashes. Now the game runs on Steam with no user information issues at all. You get to have Steam achievements and Steam tradings cards too inc ase you are into these goodies. This is the way the game should had been at release!
✔ All DLCs already there and 100% free (as I mentioned) which gives you access to the full list of cars, modes and tracks.
✔ Enriched list of OST than before. There's a seriously much larger list of OST this time. They are awesome!

CONS:
✖ Was badly optimized at release. Full screen mode was bugged and crashed but it was fixed about 2 weeks after release. However there's a serious issue with multisample anti-aliasing taking up ubnormal amount of CPU power and can cause crashes (recommended to play with MSAA turned off)
✖ For most PCs runnign Win 7 and Win 8 types of OSs the game is being installed with a .dll file missing making it unable to launch. it's a minor issue that can be solved. The fix can be found here http://steamcommunity.com/app/321040/discussions/0/611702631212584160/?insideModal=1


FINAL VERDICT:

With the exception of the minor performance issues this game is great. However many people had to do much searching to make it run properly from the start. I'm not sure how the performance issues occured during the port from Dirt 3 to Dirt 3 - Complete Edition but it's ncie to see the developers still working on it eventhough they already have a new Dirt Rally game to to work on.
The game is so exciting that I had no problem playing teh whole thing from start to end even if I already had burned myself with the old version.
it's a sweet rally experience and it still has all the 2011 graphics engine level of requirements so it can run on most of PCs (provided you are keeping in mind about the msaa issue)!
it's a 8.5/10 and totally recommended. It might had been lower for making me go through figuring out hardware issues due to its optimization, but hell free DLC and no GFWL?!?! This is how most games should be made and released like!

reviewText:
If you know what Rally is, then all you need to know is that this is the absolute best rally game on the market. It's beautiful, it sounds amazing, and it will test your skills to the limit with the assists switched off.

But what if you don't?

Rally is not racing like your dad watches on sunday afternoons. Rally is timed point-to-point all terrain racing. Instead of starting all at once or racing individually, drivers have a staggered start. One car will go, then ten seconds later another, until everyone has launched. The goal is not to finish first, the goal is to clock the shortest time between start and finish -- without wrapping your car around a tree, or hucking it off a rainslick cliff, or rolling it into a snowdrift.

Oh yes, there are no yellow flags here. You will race in the rain. You will race in the snow. You will race at night, guided only by your navigator's notes and the narrow beam of your headlights. You will race down narrow, bucking forest trails and over frozen tundra and along one-lane mountain cliff face roads and over the dry dusty desert, and you will do it in short, squat little hatchbacks with ludicrously oversized and turbocharged engines blasting absurd torque into all four wheels, still barely enough to cling to the unpaved track.

Rally does not require two hours on the circuit to test your endurance. It'll do it in five minute sprints. Ready to get dirty?

reviewText:
This is my review for the third incarnation of the DiRT series and eighth incarnation of the Colin McRae Rally series; DiRT 3. Some may not know too much of the Colin McRae name nowadays though. As a childhood fan of his, the series and rallying in general I decided to pick up this on sale in the '14 summer sale and it sat in my library doing not much for a long time until this rerelease.
As most are well aware, this version includes all DLC previously released and removes the abhorrent GFWL DRM. The visuals of the game are rather pretty especially for a game thats been around for over 4 years. The soundtrack is pretty dull but very quiet and quite easy to ignore especially as there is no in car audio, which I personally like. The driving experience is rather poor with keyboard so I would recommend using either a controller or a driving wheel if you can afford one and I'd also recommend playing on the hardest" difficulty setting and then changing the ai difficulty if needed as the game gives way too much in the form of assists. The amount of vehicles in the game is a little less than I would like but theres still enough to create variety. A large problem is the amount of tracks in the game though as each of the rallies are just one short track cut up into stages of around 30 seconds to a max of 3 minutes in length and the trailblazer tracks are almost exactly the same and I feel the cars should have longer intervals before being released from the start. Rallycross events give more variety but are rather dull in my opinion. Land Rush events are particularly annoying as they restrict to only one single vehicle which are particularly difficult to control. Gymkhana is mostly just a pain in the ♥♥♥ and can be ignored for the most part.

TL;DR Its a fun game but lacks content to be interesting for more than around 50 hours. If youre a more hardcore rallying fan the DiRT Rally may shape up to your desires but as it is in early access the end game is still quite a way away"

reviewText:
Overall I've played about 50 hours of DiRT 3, if you combine the GFWL version and the good version. The GFWL was acceptable, I mean it wasn't as bad as some people made out; it had micro transactions on some cars (which I don't really use anyway) from what I can remember and the online was much worse but I still really enjoyed it.

Good points
-The actually driving is amazing, I wouldn't say it is semi-arcady because there is no boost, or power ups (like in DiRT Showdown which is pretty good actually) and there is a lot of momentum involved when turning.
- Graphically it is very nice, lots of options and performs well.
- The tracks are great as well, there is so many and there is loads of diversity.
- Lots of racing types rally, rallycross, gymkana, trailblazer etc.

Bad points
- The better you do in a race the more driver rep you will recieve but driver rep only unlocks more cars and you're most likely to already have a car with rwd or 4wd that weighs and has the same power. To be honest I don't care about getting a car I basically already have with different cosmetics.
- Outside of the actual racing in DiRT 3 is were I feel the game has been let down because there is no customisation or upgrading, it's literally pick a car you've unlocked and race.

DiRT 3 is certainly up there with the best racing games I've played.  The one thing that separates it from other racing games in the gymkana stuff where you bascially just do tricks. To be honest If you want balls to the wall fun I would play DiRT Showdown; it's just basically DiRT 3 but the game actually likes you wrecking other peoples cars, motorstorm is good even though it's not on pc and Flatout 2 is good if you want an arcade game with destrcution. Otherwise if you want a more sporty, more serious racing game play this.

reviewText:
I'm not much into cars. I've historically hated racing games. Doesn't matter much to Dirt 3, the friendliest racing game I've probably ever come across. If you've ever just been playing a free-roam like GTA and feel like all you want is a good race, to drive fast, and get the the thrill of taking a corner and overtaking your opponent, this is your game -- and trust me, even if you don't know crap about racing, Dirt 3 will accomodate you, and leave you wanting more.

You know Top Gear? It's a great show, right? Dirt 3 is great for the same reason -- it's accessible. A person like me who drives a car for work and literally nothing else can feel like he understands by playing this game. The difficulty settings are super flexible. Whatever you're good at, you can account for it, and get assistance for the parts of driving you're maybe not so great at. The game itself is welcoming, you can get information on everything from the car you've picked, to the specific vehicle settings you've made. Once you've customized it all to your skill level, you can take to the track like a pro, and the replays (accompanied by this game's fantastic soundtrack) will make you look like you know what the hell you're doing.

I'm a complete scrublord when it comes to racing, but Dirt 3 is a fantastic showcase of the genre. Give it a shot at least, it's definitely the most accomodating racing game I've yet to come across.

reviewText:
DiRT 3 is without a doubt, one of the best racing games I've ever played. While I admit that I don't care a lot for racing games, DiRT 3 packs in enough different tracks and courses that it's enjoyable from start to finish. And this game is loaded with content. It took me 24 hours just to beat the game a single time.

Graphics are very good and the audio is also well done.

To get the most out of the game, players should definitely remove all the AI Assisting in the options so you're free to tumble and crash. It makes the game more difficult, sure, but also improves immersion a ton.

Difficulty is well balanced. The game offers 8 levels of opponent difficulty so casual racers (like myself) can enjoy a round and racing enthusiasts can also get their fix.

My only gripe is that at low speeds, the cars seem to turn like 3 trailer semi-trucks, so you're forced to drift at every-single-turn. And at those low speeds, when you start to accelerate again, the cars like to spin out easily.

Good game overall, definite recommendation for both casual and hard core race gamers.

reviewText:
I'm not much into cars. I've historically hated racing games. Doesn't matter much to Dirt 3, the friendliest racing game I've probably ever come across. If you've ever just been playing a free-roam like GTA and feel like all you want is a good race, to drive fast, and get the the thrill of taking a corner and overtaking your opponent, this is your game -- and trust me, even if you don't know crap about racing, Dirt 3 will accomodate you, and leave you wanting more.

You know Top Gear? It's a great show, right? Dirt 3 is great for the same reason -- it's accessible. A person like me who drives a car for work and literally nothing else can feel like he understands by playing this game. The difficulty settings are super flexible. Whatever you're good at, you can account for it, and get assistance for the parts of driving you're maybe not so great at. The game itself is welcoming, you can get information on everything from the car you've picked, to the specific vehicle settings you've made. Once you've customized it all to your skill level, you can take to the track like a pro, and the replays (accompanied by this game's fantastic soundtrack) will make you look like you know what the hell you're doing.

I'm a complete scrublord when it comes to racing, but Dirt 3 is a fantastic showcase of the genre. Give it a shot at least, it's definitely the most accomodating racing game I've yet to come across.

reviewText:
Il gioco cerca di cambiare atmosfera distaccandosi dal suo predecessore.Rispetto a DIRT2 il gioco si concentra molto di più su gare Rally divise ovviamente in altre 3 sezioni e sulla nuova aggiunta,ovvero la Gimkana(è una gara all'aperto nella quale i concorrenti devono percorrere un tracciato tortuoso e reso impegnativo da ostacoli, nel più breve tempo e con il minor numero di penalità possibili).
Purtroppo il gioco pecca nella parte della campagna,la quale in DIRT3 è meno caratterizzata rispetto a quella di DIRT2,si vede che la Codemaster non ha più voglia di concentrarsi su questo aspetto visto che pure  con la serie F1 da F1 2010 hanno smesso di produrre una campagna decente,per non parlare di GRID.Comunque la modalità storia è composta da 4 stagioni con tante sfide da completare,essa servirà prevalentemente solo per salire di livello e sbloccare nuove auto oppure livrea per queste ultime.
Da  quanto il gioco è passato da GFWL a Steam   si può avere la Complete Edition,la quale ci offrirà tutti i DLC  usciti per DIRT3 che comprendono  nuove auto.
La modalità su cui DIRT3 si bassa maggiormente è appunto la Gimkana,modalità che sarà presentata da Ken Block ovvero il miglior pilota per quanto riguarda questo sport.
Il comparto multiplayer è ottimo e da quanto  hanno abbandonato GFWL è di nuovo ripopolato anche se prima  si poteva giocare pure contro la gente che aveva DIRT3 su XBOX360.Purtroppo le varie modalità,ovviamente  cambia anche in base a come sono impostate le gare,vengono rovinate dai giocatori che provano sempre a spingerti fuori pista,a fari testacoda oppure a danneggiarti facendoti ritirare
Nel gioco era presenta anche la possibilità di pubblicare i propri video su Youtube,modalità che non ha mai funzionato ed è stata tolta nella versione Steam.
Per quanto riguarda il lato tecnico,il gioco è magnifico,ovviamente ha alle spalle ben 4 anni però non sfigura affatto.Pure per quanto riguarda il lato ottimizzazione è un gioco leggerissimo,come  tutta la serie DIRT,nel 2011 lo giocai con  una scheda video Nvidia 9500gt da 1gb GDDR2 ed andava sui 40 frame tutto ad alto,mentre ora con una ATI\AMD 7750 supera anche  i  100 frame.
In conclusione DIRT3 è un buon gioco ma che per me rimane nel ombra di DIRT2 anche se possiede  un ottime modalità  come quella gimkana ed un multiplayer più  divertente.Speriamo solo che se faranno un DIRT4 sia un mix tra DIRT2 e 3.

This review is going to focus mainly on this version of the games performance with my Logitech G27. The sequential shifters work great, as they should, but the clutch pedal is utter rubbish. I missed roughly 80% of the shifts with the way it's set up, and I couldn't find a way to adjust deadzones or sensitivity. The H-pattern shifter still works great without the clutch though, so that's a plus.

The game does not support 900° rotation, which is a huge negative for me in any racing game.

I still recommend the game though, it is great fun, and works exactly as you expect it to with a controller. With a wheel, just realize the games limitations. The 270° or so that you can get out of the wheel does work well about 95% of the time, ibut t's rather unacceptable on hairpin turns and makes correcting the car that much harder in certain situations.

Disclaimer: Not a review, more like a '20 seconds into the game impression'.

I really must say that the difficulty settings are broken. It doesn't make sense that I can finish every single race 1st on 'casual' mode with zero effort (read: full throttle, only having to steer along the indicated path), yet consistently trash my car and finish last with the 'intermediate' setting.

I'm playing with a keyboard, but I think the whole auto-braking stuff makes the game WAY too easy on 'casual', yet fairly inconsistent at 'intermediate'. It also seems this game simply wasn't tested properly with a keyboard setup.

To make things even more strange... the highest difficulty setting actually feels more responsive. This has to do with how it seems less prone to overshooting when steering. The game also really has some strange physics when playing on keyboard. Occassionally the entire input seems just plain gone and at other times it overshoots and can't be corrected. All this aside the game looks and sounds great, with the only thing bothering me a bit is stuff you can't skip in terms of unnecessary voice overs introducing the super obvious.

It's still recommended, but don't expect a reasonable gameplay experience with keyboard. The dev ignored such a setup completely it seems.

reviewText:
This game was amazing even before the Complete Edition of this, but yet Games for Windows Live was horrible, especially sense it was running alongside steam which made things more difficult, later Microsoft took dwon Windows Live, which partially broke the game and multiplayer. Dirt 3, along with Dirt 2 are one of the best racing games out there, especially if you like Rally or other types of racing.
--------
Dirt 3 Gameplay: The game has very nice physics, the cars just have the right amount of understeer and oversteer, and each car handles completely differently, and they are all fun to drive. With this, there's a ton of disiplines and modes. The graphics and damage physics also make the game much mroe immersive. There is a decently long campaign in the game, and single races where you can customize them, and multiplayer and more!
--------
Dirt 3 Graphics: This is a bit of an older game, but the graphics are still pretty good and satisfying, especially when it came out. The textures may be a bit blurry nowadays though. There are plenty of special effects especially on the cars, your car gets dirtier as you drive (depending on what you're driving on), and again car physics make it even better. There is also different weather systems in the game, such as snow, evening, morning, night, fog, etc (May vary with certain maps). The environments are also beautiful and are completely different from eachother.
--------
DLC: Well this is the complete package, you are getting the whole game. The DLC includes a few maps and cars, which are all pretty good.
--------
Dirt 3 Physics (and Damage system): Going along with gameplay, the physics is really what brings people in. The cars are completely effected by the track, such as snow and ice being more slippy, and the damage physics are great, if you have full damaged turned on you can damage your tires, gradually popping them, and also damage your engine, and there's a few more minor things to be damaged, all damage is soft body, and a bunch of components on your car can fall off; such as bumpers, fenders, cracks and dents, exhaust, windows can break and crack, and more. All cars have different damage physics as well.
--------
April Fools update (It was actually legit): Thanks codemasters for giving this out for free if we owned Dirt 3, removing Games for Windows Live, and including all DLC and making things free, so I'll be coming back to this game every now and then.
--------
I have over 300+ hours on the real game (not the complete package), both pretty much the same thing, and I enjoyed all moments of it. Once you complete the campaign move to multiplayer, maybe invite some friends, and have a blast, or you can do some of your own customized races and also challenge yourself and review cars, or just mess around overall. There's a lot of freedom in this game.     [ I give it a 9/10 ] It could use longer maps here and there and a few minor improvements.
--------
Overall a great game, even if you are just into racing and maybe not all of this rally, trailblazer, etc stuff, you will still like this game.
--------
I may add more to this later, let me know if I need to add anything else, and thanks for reading. Go ahead and leave comments if you wish as well.

TL;DR - Dirt 2 amazing but was one of the sacrifices to bring down the evil Games for Windows Live. May we honour Dirt 2's memory. Also Dirt 3 is horrendous.

For the five hours I played the game, I can only remember one bad thing; the god-awful monster truck-ish sections where the vehicles handed like you were racing frigates. Despite this one collosal flaw, which could be avoided even in Career Mode by simply not playing the Monster Frigate races, Dirt 2 was a perfect racing game, easily one of the best I'd played in 5 years.

Fast forward a Steam sale and the atrocity that was GfWL being replaced by Steamworks, I was super hyped for Dirt 3, it looked amazing, like Dirt 3 but *bigger*, new tracks, new cars, more fun to be had. As it stands, Codemasters ♥♥♥♥♥♥ all over my hopes and dreams.

So after booting up and closing what appeared to be a ghost-process three times, it turned out that upon booting and showing the Dirt 3 logo, the game actually minimizes to an unselectable window with no taskbar button. Alright, ok, that's a bit meh but I can work around that with Task Manager, so that's fine.

At this point, I'd *really* like to go to the options menu and sort out the graphics since I'd rather not play a game with 800*600 resolution and deafining levels of volume, but instead, I get a young lady talking at me, and I'm not allowed to skip. In fact as it happens, you can't skip *anything*, which is ♥♥♥♥ing horrible. I should never have to wait for someone who has absolutely no impact on the game talk at me for a good five minutes just so I can drive a car sideways in the snow. Ever. Seriously, Codemasters, this is one of the worst things you could ever do in anything. That shitey new Forza game does that and even the Top Gear presenters don't allow devs to get away with this ♥♥♥♥. Never do it again.

I finally get around to actually playing the game, through the weird nonsensical triangular menus and find that all the brilliant game feel of Dirt 2 has not made it into it's sequel. Cars fly into the air at the slightest jump at the lowest of speeds, and yet they slide endlessly sideways as though they have infinite weight.

Collosal physics issues aside, the biggest issue for me is part of the controls. When one drifts or powerslides (whatever you wish to name it), the idea is that the back end of the car swings out and the driver steers in the opposite direction, applying power to keep the drift going and to turn however tightly or for however long they desire whilst not spinning out. Dirt 3 does the opposite of this, once the back end of the car is swinging out, if one applies power, and thusly forward motion, what actually happens is the car slides off horizontally. Endlessly.

reviewText:
Rally Racing is the extreme variant of race car driving. It takes the concepts of making a car do laps and blows it up to it's logical intensity. As such, a lot of people are put off of the event from the sheer fact that it requires more concentration and skill to master.

Dirt 3 is for one type of fan; a fan that loves extreme sports. If you tire of seeing asphalt and tire marks, then jump into the Dirt! This game excels at its prime goal and doesn't do injustice to its name or legacy. With a staggering amount of game modes and an extensive career, Dirt 3 will keep you busy for a long time.

While the menu is a bit combersome, the events are easy to understand. Different types get unlocked as you progress and they all have some variation on the standard point-to-point race type typically associated with rally racing. You get Trailer Blazer (basically Rally but with a muscle car), RallyX (an opponent based, head to head rally race), Head2Head (a unique variant of drag with simultaneous paths), Gymkhana (basically trick mode), and LandRush (Buggies and Trucks, oh my!).

The campaign might get long in the tooth towards the end, but each level is meticulously designed to be replayable until your eyes bleed. You will notice subtle details each time you make turns or blaze past your opponents. The Direct X 11 support is some of the best I've ever seen on PC (and this is coming from a console based port!).

The variation in settings does a lot to break up the length of the career mode. Even without the DLC accounted for, each area is distinct in atmosphere and climate. Only Kenya will have dirt roads and only the Netherlands has snow. Each weather variant adds a whole different strategy to how you approach turns or overtake opponents.

For that matter, the online component is flawless. There are a few additional game modes, too. They are basically new takes on classic shooter game modes with capture the flag and infection (deathmatch) making an appearance. You are also given access to the DC Compound online, which is essentially a free roaming area where you can bust tricks and search for hidden icons.

The DC Compound rounds out the single-player mode, as well. If you get bored with racing for a bit, you can jump over to the compound and complete an extensive list of bonus missions. They may not offer up much in terms of reward, but setting your sights on a different set of requirements allows one to hone their skills without the pressure of a timer or rivals.

To cap off everything, Dirt 3 has one of the best learning curves I've experienced in any racing game. While the DC Challenges will destroy your body, mind and soul upon first encountering them, the way in which each campaign event trains your basic skills is so organic that you will never even notice yourself getting better.

You might struggle with breaking a high score in Gymkhana or nailing a speed-run time, but if you just progress through the career and come back, you will almost certainly have subtlely learned how to perform the best tricks and maneuvers to cut seconds off of your time.

That the game doesn't prevent you from gaining new cars with arbitrary money limitations is just icing on the cake. By playing more and getting better, you eventually will have every vehicle at your disposal. Such an elegant system is wonderful to behold.

About my only problem with this game comes from the inclusion of the DLC from the get-go. Extra events are added that aren't necessarily harder and some pretty high-level cars are given to you at the start. This allows you to blow past the career mode with ease, should you choose to go that route.

It is a little unfortunate as it undermines how well thought-out progression was in the base version of the game, but I suppose paying for that extra content (originally) would be pointless if it was locked out. I really think Codemasters should have rethought the reputation system for the PC release of Complete".

And to address the big elephant in the room
date: Steamworks is great. Dirt 3 is absent of any trapping from GfWL. This means that there are no infuriating crashes or unstable performance. Everything is flawless and friends can easily be joined from Steam. That it was given as a free upgrade to existing owners is amazing.\n\nThe only way I wouldn't recommend Dirt 3 is if you really just don't like rally racing games. If you fancy a more wild experience on wheels or just want something different
recommended: don't hesitate to grab this game.\n\n9/10"
